document.text: Yes, the Raiders with a 7-0 record after a 33-6 victory over Nelson are 1 in the Seminole district. We saw a lot of action from the Raiders in last Fridays game when they seized their 7 straight win over the Gover nors. Reynolds in the first quarter carried the ball 39 yards for the Raiders and came 1 yard from the score. Nelson held the Raiders from scoring. Both Reynolds  Trent moved the ball into good position for the Raiders  with 251 left in the 2nd period of play Trent went through standing up to make the first score of the game. Coleman making the P.A.T. on a kick, gave the Raiders the first lead of 7-0. All of the Raiders defensive plays helped to shut-out Nelson from scoring in the first half. At halftime the Raiders had 10 first downs and Nelson only had 3. Wouldnt you say the Raiders defense did a terrific job? After a delightful halftime showing by Nelsons Homecom ing activities, it was time once again for football. And football it was When with 637 left in the third quarter, Trent broke through the middle and galloped 67 long yards to set the Raider fans wild! Coleman again split the uprights for the P.A.T. The Raiders were now out front 14-0. It was not long after that when Trent, on the same play, carried the ball 55 yards to score his third TD for the game. Tommy Bryant, the kicker for the Raiders, put his foot into one and backed the Governors receiving team into the end zone. Bryant has done a tremendous job this season for the Raiders. Reynolds would have had the 4th score for the Raiders but a penalty of illegal procedure called the touchdown back. Reynolds played a good game and is a strong link in the Raiders offensive chain.

document.text: With two straight victories to their credit, the Appomattox high school football boys journey l to morrow to Clarksville to try to make it three in a row. Last Friday, the team played a bang-up game to give the Staunton V. S. D. B . its first defeat in three seasons. The core was 12 to 7. IiLthe quarter, Appo mattox came tu fm behind to mark up the winning tally on a recovered punt fumble, a pass from Tuerman to Cabell and a line buck by Turk man . Tureman turned in a spark ling game in the local backfleld, and the entire Appomattox line played a great game, althought outweighed by Staunton. That Appomattox will have a hard garnT tomorrow is indicated by the fact that Clarksville recently de feated Farmville and lost by only _ one touchdown to Altavista. Several shifts in the line-up may be necessary tomorrow. The mighty atom, Ivanhoe Bryant, is ou. wi n an injured ankle, and R.B. Hudg.ns Jr. and Buck Wallace will fill in  at center for Chuck Lrgon.

document.text: With only one weeks practice be hind them, but with an impressive list of veteran players, the Appo mattox high school football team journeys to Bedford tomorrow after noon for the opening game on a difficult schedule. Coach Charles A. HHt indicated today that he would test out several combinations during the game, and hoped to make a creditable showing against the strong Bedford eleven. Although five lettermen from last years team are missing due to grad uation, Coach Hilt has enough vet eran material available to start a letter-winner at each position if he so desires. However, several of the new players are showing up so well in practice that several new men may be in the starting line-up. Captain Jack Turman and three other lettermen are available for baclcfield duty. The backfield candi dates include Captain Turman, Har ry Burge, Ivanhoe Bryant, David Christian, Billy Ould, Harold Caw- thorn, William Mitchell, Charles Bryant and James Garrett. At the end position, the coach has Guy Cabell, Buck Wallace, La- than Harvey, Julian Hesson, Her man Dee and Buck Smith. Tackle candidates are Tom Guill, Buster Moore, Robert AHjen Sears, and James Spiggle. At center, Chester Ligon and J. E. Carson Jr. are vieing for the starting nod. Guard aspirants are Sid Conner, Joe Ferrell, Roy Craw ley, Frank Miller, Pete -Evans and Andrew Paulette. New j era ays, helmets, shoes and pants have been purchased, and the blue and white team will have a snappy eappearance. The first home game will not be played until October 13. document.text: Winners in the Football Contest sponsored by local m erchants have been an nounced by the TIMES-VIR- GINIAN for the contest in the November 2, 1978 edition of this newspaper. Jefferson Forest - William Campbell did not play each other in Friday nights game so we will not count that as one of the contest games. With a possible 22 correct predictions to make in this contest, Raymond W. Bryant of Route 3, Appomattox correctly picked 21 games. He is winner of first place and will receive a check from the TIMES-VIR-  GINIAN in the. amount of 10.00 as first place prize. Correctly picking 20 of the games from the possible 22  games listed in the contest were Nelwyn Morris of Route 3, Robert I. Scott of 510 Virginia Avenue, Leoh Bryant, Jr. of Route 3, and Steve Mitchell of P. 0. Box 132. Going to the tie-breakers for a winner, Steve Mitchell was the only one of the four to pick Air Force to beat Army which was incorrect. Going to the Appo mattox - Amherst game for a winner, Robert I. Scott with an 8 point difference in the game is winner of second place and will receive a check. from the TIMES-VIRGINIAN in the amount of 5.00 as second place prize. Appomattox won over Amherst by only 2 points. As this was the last game of the season for the Seminole District, of which Appomattox Raiders are Champions, the -frxA bottcontegt W itt  k UrtWrt until next season. Congratula tions to all the winners and to the participants in the contest this year. It truly created a great deal of interest.

document.text: Wilton H. Bryant Wilton Haywood Bryant, 71, of Wright Shop Road, Madison Heights, died Wed nesday, May 21, in Lynch burg General Hospital. He was the husband of Mattie Proffit Bryant. Born in Appomattox Co unty, he was a son of the late Floyd Bryant and Nannie Vest Bryant. He was a retired employee of Virginia Greenstone and, at the time of his death, was Employed by Quality Foods, Inc. He was a member of United Pentecostal Church. In addition to his wife, he is survived by five sons, Haywood T. Bxyant of Amherst, Thomas H. Bryan of Rustburg, Howard W. Bryant of Concord, Elwood W. Bryant and Russell L. Bryant, both of Lynchburg two daughters, Frances B. Staten  jn d Sandra F. Bryant, both of Madison Heights a brother! Loyd Bryant of Amherst a sister, Virginia Connelly of Madi son Heights 14 grand children and four great grandchildren. Funeral services Were conducted. 11 a.m. Friday . in Whitten Park Avenue Chapel by Pastor James A. Wolfe. Interment was ip,  Meade .Cemetery.

document.text: Willard D. Ligon, a native of Appomattox County, general manager of the Bryant division of the Westinghouse Electric corporation, who will retire December 31, 1972, was honored on November 12th, at a reception in the Holiday Inn, Bridgeport, Connecticut. The December, 1972, issue Westinghouse New, Bryant division, was entirely dedicat ed to him and was headed The Ligon Years - A Lasting Legacy. Along side a large picture of Mr. Ligon on the front page of the company newspaper, was the following What A Way To Go - Flags flying, Bands playing and Bryant surpassing all expect- ions! Yes, the Ligon years have been a lasting legacy. A legacy of unparalleled growth and accomplishment. A period of years marked by continued employment and new product development. To Willard Du- puy Ligon, as a testimonial to your 43 year Westinghouse career and its spectacular conclusion at Bryant Electric, we dedicate this issue of the Westinghouse News. Ligon was appointed General Manager of the Bryant Divi sion of the Westinghouse Corporation in 1963, having joined the company in 1929, after graduating from Virginia Polytechnic Institute with a B.S. in industrial engineering. A native of Pamplin, Virginia, he graduated from Blackstone Military Institute prior to attending V.P.I., Blacksburg, Virginia. He is married to the former Mary Brightwell of Pamplin. His first Westinghouse as signment was as a foreman in the Motor Division at East Pittsburg, Pa. He rose to general foreman, assistant superintendent and superin tendent. While in this division, at the end of World War II, Mr. Ligon was moved to Buffalo, New York, along with the division, and served as resident manager and then was appointed manager of the Motor Division. He was named general works manager of the combined Motor and Control Divisions at Buffalo in 1950. In 1951, he moved to Sunnyvale, California, to become project manager at the Westinghouse plant in charge of building

document.text: WHO WILL BE THE LAUREATE? The death of Tennyson raises in literary circles the question of the most fitting man to succeed him as the Laureateof England. From the telegraphic reports it would seem that the English public sentiment points to but three men as at all worthy to aspire to this great digni tySwinburne, Sir Edwin Arnold, and William Morris. The occasion naturally excites the reflection that the death of Tennyson leaves the Ffogliah speaking race, for the first time in the present century at least, without a first class ooet , without a poet of the second lass w hollr pure anti inspiring verse has imbedded itself in the memory and admiration of mankind. The poetic dearth-is particularly notable on thin side.of the Atlantic. There never were but three real poets in AmarfeaPoe, Bryant, and Longfel low. These are all gone. W hittier possessed some measure of poetic in stinct with a certain gift of vivid versification, without being a genuine poet. He, too, hta re cently passed away. Holmes wrote occasional verses but made no claim to a place among . the inspired singers. Our Hall of Poesy is now a silent chamber,

document.text: While substituting at the library last summer, I had several calls for the book, Dog Days at the White House by Traphes Bryant. At that time the library did not have a copy but since then I have been informed that we now have two copies, one of which was sent by mail from Buckingham County with a note but no name signed. Thank you, anonymous donor, whoever you are. Since sixteen new books have been processed in the last two weeks, one would think it easy to find one, but believe it or not, they are all checked out and the readers clamoring for more. I managed to get two, which I read as quickly as possible and took back for others. Remem ber, it is important to do this even tho the time limit is two weeks. Never keep a new book that long if you can possibly read it more quickly, as others are waiting and wishing. The two which I read were Curtain by Agatha Christie and The i Greek Treasure by Irvin g Stone. Curtain was written in the miH 1940s and was intended to be published after her death, but for some reason, she changed her mind and released it for publication this year. This is one of her better books and will probably be classed with such Christie classics as The Murder of Roger Ackroyd The A.B.C. Murders and Ten Little Indians. Henry Schliemann, the hero of The Greek Treasure, had no formal education past his 14th birthday, yet he spoke and wrote 18 languages. The book is a love story, adventure story and archaeology combined. Sophia Mrs. Schliemann was a IT year old Greek beauty who married Schliemann mainly to help her family, financially. A very pretty glrf was talking to an elderly man. They were standing by the window In th lounging room facing Bryant Park. Oh, Colonel, said the young lady, just look at those trees! Arent they beautiful? Yes, to some extent, replied th old warrior but- Why, dont you like trees? Intec rupted the girl. Indeed I do! document.text: When court opened here Monday a large ciowd was present the mat ter of intense interest being the Sears-Ilarvey murder trial. Three Juries and about seventy-five wit nesses had been summoneu by Sher iff McKinney besides these the rel atives and close friends on each side of the unfortunate affair were on hand, and showed as much in terest in the pioceedings as the principals. Mr. Thomas Watkins one of the ablest criminal lawyers of the State has been secured to conduct the case for the Common wealth, who will be aided by that talented young lawyer from Am herst, Mr. Aubrey E. Strode. Con gressman Flood is looking after the defence side of the case. The Grand Jury indicted Sears for murder of Harvey and the prisoner, who was out on bail ap peared in court and answered the indictment. The application for bail was made and the Judge con tinued it until morning on the mo tion of defence, and Sears was plac ed in jail for the night. On Tuesday morning the court beard the evideuce of the defence for the purpose of granting bail, at the conclusion of which the J odge granted bail m the sum of ten thousand dollars for the appear ance of the prisoner on the second day of the next erm of court, which will be the 24th day of July. Sears takes the stand and relates the story of the killing of Harvey, which was substantially as follows I was co lector of taxes my bio- ther was collector, 1 was not old enough, and he qualified and gave me the place he trouble occurred between store and shop 1 first saw Harvey as I was oil my way to col lect some scattering tickets beyond his place I bad collected Harveys ticket 1 was on my way to Dicker- sons I saw Bryant and be told me to come by aud he would pay mt we went together to Rose Bo wet saw Harvey Harvey asked about Woodsons tuxes Harvey asked about bis old ticket and said he hadnt received it I went on and came back to Rose Bower as I ode up Harvey asked if I had seeu Woodson, I said 1 had been toGoiua and would have to get him to send his taxes up to Appomattox he cursed the collector and I told him he was my brother, and he start.-d to nsing oaths again I dropped the matter and inquired the way to Gallegtiers colected Galleghers taxes and cume back to Rote Bow er, and rode up and told Bryant if he was ready we would go up to Vera together. document.text: Whatever ehance Appomattox County had of going through 1955 without a highway fatality, went glimmering about midnight Satur day. It was undoubtedly one of the worst car wrecks in the history of the county, two youn me met in stant death and two others remain in critical condition, following the crashing of a speeding car over an embankment and into a tree about four miles this side of Bent Creek on Route 26. The dead Cecil Howell -Stephens, 26, of Route 2, Gladstone, and Raymond Edward Jamerson, 29. also of Route 2, Gladstone. At latest reports, two other occu pants of the death car were still un conscious and in a very critical con dition at a Lynchburg hospital. They are Carl Bryant, 19, and Calvin Phelps, 28, both of Route 2, Gladstone. It is understood that Bryant and Phelps have fractures of the skull and leg. The death car plunged over the left side of Route 26, dopvn an em bankment and literally wrapped it self around a tree. The ear jack knifed, badly mangling the victims. After the car was prized from the tree, and brought to Appomattox Sunday morning, large crowds gath ered all during the day to view the wreckage. Other crowds drove to the wreck site on Route 26. State Police who investigated the crash, declared that high speed was the obvious cause of the wreck. These deaths started Appomattox County off into 1955 with no chance of bettering its 1954 highway death toll. Last vear there was only one highway death in the county, and that, too, occurred in January. In 1953. the county also had only one highway death.
